title: [bug] Indirect python_requires with version range from cache not found
body:
### Environment details

* Operating System+version: Linux Ubuntu 22.04
* Conan version: 2.0.4
* Python version: 3.10.6

A python_requires package with a version range fails to be found in the local cache (even though a package matching the version range exists) when indirectly required through another package (via normal "requires"). 

Same scenario with a fixed version in the python_requires works.

### Steps to reproduce

Create a trivial package to serve as a python_requires:
```
$ mkdir pr
$ cd pr
$ conan new basic
```
Edit `conanfile.py`. Set package name to "pr". Create package in cache:
```
$ conan create .
```
Create a second package that uses the first as python_requires:
```
$ cd ..
$ mkdir use_pr
$ cd use_pr
$ conan new basic
```
Edit `conanfile.py`. Set package name to "use_pr". Add a line to the class header:
```
    python_requires = "pr/[>0]"
```
(Actually any version range, that includes the version of the "pr" package, will do.)
Create the package in cache:
```
$ conan create .
```
Package will be created without a problem (i. e. the pr/1.0 package will be found and used from cache).
Now create a third basic conan package:
```
$ cd ..
$ mkdir use_use_pr
$ cd use_use_pr
$ conan new basic
```
Edit `conanfile.py`. Set package name to e. g. `use_use_pr`. Add `use_pr/1.0` as normal requirement:
```
    def requirements(self):
        self.requires( "use_pr/1.0")
```
Try to create the package:
```
$ conan create .
```
Package creation will fail, because `pr`-package cannot be found, even though it is in the cache.

### Logs

```
$ conan create .
======== Exporting recipe to the cache ========
use_use_pr/1.0: Exporting package recipe: /home/user/tmp/20230424-conan2-bug-version_range_in_python_requires_when_in_local_cache/use_use_pr-package/conanfile.py
use_use_pr/1.0: Copied 1 '.py' file: conanfile.py
use_use_pr/1.0: Exported to cache folder: /home/user/.conan2/p/use_uc889bfa0cf41d/e
use_use_pr/1.0: Exported: use_use_pr/1.0#b1b720ecaeac4d8f07cde7a0c6369d75 (2023-04-24 18:05:46 UTC)

======== Input profiles ========
Profile host:
[settings]
arch=x86_64
build_type=RelWithDebInfo
compiler=gcc
compiler.cppstd=gnu17
compiler.libcxx=libstdc++11
compiler.version=11
os=Linux

Profile build:
[settings]
arch=x86_64
build_type=RelWithDebInfo
compiler=gcc
compiler.cppstd=gnu17
compiler.libcxx=libstdc++11
compiler.version=11
os=Linux


======== Computing dependency graph ========
pr/[>0]: Not found in local cache, looking in remotes...
pr/[>0]: Checking remote: conan-rme
Graph root
    cli
Requirements
    use_use_pr/1.0#b1b720ecaeac4d8f07cde7a0c6369d75 - Cache
*********************************************************
Recipe 'use_pr/1.0' seems broken.
It is possible that this recipe is not Conan 2.0 ready
If the recipe comes from ConanCenter check: https://conan.io/cci-v2.html

```

title: [question] CMakeToolchain generates CMAKE_SYSTEM_NAME baremetal instead of Generic?
body:

I'm running 2.0.2 and trying to cross compile for a bare metal target setting `os=baremetal`  in the respective profile. I was expecting `CMakeToolchain` to generate `CMAKE_SYSTEM_NAME` to `Generic` but it stuck with `baremetal`. Anything I'm missing or just something not considered yet?

title: [bug] Failure to resolve python-requires required by a python-requires when it only exists on a remote and not the local cache
body:
## Environment details

* Operating System+version: Arch Linux
* Compiler+version: clang 15
* Conan version: 2.0.3
* Python version: 3.11.1

I've also replicated this within a standard conanio docker environment.

## Steps to reproduce

### Replicate the failure
1. Create a blank project
```bash
$ mkdir pyrequire_bug && cd pyrequire_bug
$ conan new cmake_lib -d name=foo -d version=0.1.0
```
2. Apply the following diff to `conanfile.py`:
```diff
diff --git a/conanfile.py b/conanfile.py
index 745af9c..0355c59 100644
--- a/conanfile.py
+++ b/conanfile.py
@@ -20,6 +20,7 @@ class fooRecipe(ConanFile):
 
     # Sources are located in the same place as this recipe, copy them to the recipe
     exports_sources = "CMakeLists.txt", "src/*", "include/*"
+    python_requires = "cmake-python-deps/[>=0.3.0]@mtolympus/stable"
 
     def config_options(self):
         if self.settings.os == "Windows":
```
3. Add the `mtolympus` remote:
```bash
$ conan remote add mtolympus-conan https://mtolympus.jfrog.io/artifactory/api/conan/mtolympus-conan
```
4. Attempt to install
```bash
$ conan install .
```

At which point it fails with the error below.

### Circumvent the failure
Now what _does_ work, is if i try to install this as a package
```bash
$ conan install --requires cmake-python-deps/0.3.0@mtolympus/stable --build=missing
```

title: [question] How to download remote artifact by options?
body:
### What is your question?

Hi!
I would like to download built packages from a self-hosted remote. Also, I would like to download only the packages that have had certain options/settings during their build.
Let's say I have two **P** packages. One was built with the **with_gpu_support** option **True** and the other with **False**. I want to be able to specify to `conan download` to only consider packages of **P** that were built with GPU support.

I couldn't find any option specifiers for the download command, not any other for that matter. I searched around, and it was somewhat possible to do this previous of conan 2.0 by listing all **P** package config options:
`conan search P --remote=my_remote --options`
and then cherry picking the correct artifacts after parsing them in python for example. 

Why was this removed in 2.0 and is there a solution to my problem? I think it is a rather common use case.

### Have you read the CONTRIBUTING guide?

- [X] I've read the CONTRIBUTING guide

title: [bug] `conan remove <ref> -p <query>` removes all packages and recipe instead of packages matching query
body:
### Environment details

* Operating System+version: Ubuntu 22.04
* Compiler+version: doesn't matter
* Conan version: 2.0.2
* Python version: 3.10.6


### Steps to reproduce

Install & build several recipes with clang & gcc

call `conan remove "*" -p "compiler=clang" -c`. All packages AND recipes themselves are removed, instead of removing only clang packages.

Example:

`conan list "zlib/*:*#*"`

title: [bug] Packages linked with static libraries cannot be used in editable mode
body:
# Environment details
* Operating system: Rocky Linux 8.7
* Compiler: GCC 8.5.0
* Conan version: 2.0.2
* Python version: 3.9.13

# Steps to reproduce
## Create a package A in a folder

Copy the following conanfile.py

```python
from conan import ConanFile
from conan.tools.cmake import CMake, CMakeToolchain, CMakeDeps, cmake_layout
from conan.tools.env import Environment, VirtualBuildEnv, VirtualRunEnv
from conan.tools.files import copy, collect_libs

class Pkg(ConanFile):
	required_conan_version = ">=1.50.0"
	name = "A"
	version = "1.0"

	# Binary configuration
	settings = "os", "compiler", "build_type", "arch"
	options = {
		"shared": [True, False],
		"fPIC": [True, False],
	}
	default_options = {
		"shared": False,
		"fPIC": True,
	}

	def export_sources(self):
		copy(self, "*.c*", src=self.recipe_folder, dst=self.export_sources_folder)
		copy(self, "*CMakeLists.txt", src=self.recipe_folder, dst=self.export_sources_folder)

	def build_requirements(self):
		self.test_requires("gtest/1.13.0")

	def config_options(self):
		if self.settings.os == "Windows":
			del self.options.fPIC

	def layout(self):
		cmake_layout(self)

	def generate(self):
		vr = VirtualRunEnv(self)
		vr.generate()
		ct = CMakeToolchain(self)
		ct.generate()
		cd = CMakeDeps(self)
		cd.generate()

	def build(self):
		cmake = CMake(self)
		cmake.configure()
		cmake.build()
```

Copy the following CMakeLists.txt


```cmake
cmake_minimum_required(VERSION 3.23)

set(CMAKE_CXX_STANDARD_REQUIRED True)
set(CMAKE_CXX_STANDARD 17)
set(PROJECT_NAME test)

project(${PROJECT_NAME} LANGUAGES CXX)

find_package(GTest)

add_library(${PROJECT_NAME})

target_sources(${PROJECT_NAME}
	PRIVATE
		a.cpp
)

target_link_libraries(${PROJECT_NAME}
	PRIVATE
		gtest::gtest
)
```

Copy the following source file *a.cpp*
```cpp
#include <gtest/gtest.h>

std::string	hello()
{
	return "Hello";
}

TEST(testMath, test_hello)
{
    EXPECT_EQ("Hello", hello());
}
```

Run the following command :
```shell
conan build . -verror --settings "&:build_type=Debug" --options="A/*:shared=True" --build=missing
```

A *libtest.so* is successfully created in build/Debug. It is linked with a static version of gtest.

Mark the reciped as editable with
```shell
conan editable add .
```

The command returns
```shell
Reference 'A/1.0' in editable mode
```

## Create a package B in another folder

Copy the following conanfile.py

```python
from conan import ConanFile
from conan.tools.cmake import CMake, CMakeToolchain, CMakeDeps, cmake_layout
from conan.tools.env import Environment, VirtualBuildEnv, VirtualRunEnv
from conan.tools.files import copy, collect_libs

class Pkg(ConanFile):
	required_conan_version = ">=1.50.0"
	name = "B"
	version = "1.0"

	# Binary configuration
	settings = "os", "compiler", "build_type", "arch"
	options = {
		"shared": [True, False],
		"fPIC": [True, False],
	}
	default_options = {
		"shared": False,
		"fPIC": True,
	}

	def export_sources(self):
		copy(self, "*.c*", src=self.recipe_folder, dst=self.export_sources_folder)
		copy(self, "*CMakeLists.txt", src=self.recipe_folder, dst=self.export_sources_folder)

	def requirements(self):
		self.requires("A/1.0")
	def config_options(self):
		if self.settings.os == "Windows":
			del self.options.fPIC

	def layout(self):
		cmake_layout(self)

	def generate(self):
		vr = VirtualRunEnv(self)
		vr.generate()
		ct = CMakeToolchain(self)
		ct.generate()
		cd = CMakeDeps(self)
		cd.generate()

	def build(self):
		cmake = CMake(self)
		cmake.configure()
		cmake.build()
```

Copy the following CMakeLists.txt


```cmake
cmake_minimum_required(VERSION 3.23)

set(CMAKE_CXX_STANDARD_REQUIRED True)
set(CMAKE_CXX_STANDARD 17)
set(PROJECT_NAME test)

project(${PROJECT_NAME} LANGUAGES CXX)

add_executable(${PROJECT_NAME})

target_sources(${PROJECT_NAME}
	PRIVATE
		b.cpp
)
```

Copy the following source file *b.cpp*
```cpp
int	main()
{
	return 0;
}
```

Run the command
```shell
conan build . -verror --settings "&:build_type=Debug" --build=missing
```

The following error shows up:
```shell
ERROR: A/1.0: Error in generate() method, line 49
        cd.generate()
        ConanException: error generating context for 'gtest/1.13.0': include is not absolute
```

**Expected results** : Package B should compile without any issue.

From my understanding, this happens whenever a shared library links with a static one. Compiling gtest as a shared library fixes the issue. However, gtest is usually compiled as a static library.

The issue also happens:
- While using Boost as a dependency and compiled as a shared library. I get the same error with libbacktrace, even though it is not a direct dependency of my project (but used by Boost).
- With any non direct dependency that I didn't specify to be built as shared ones.

**Might be another bug** : self.options does not affect packages added with test_requirements. (e.g: gtest)

title: [bug] In the CMakeDeps Generator CONAN_FOUND_LIBRARY and CONAN_SHARED_FOUND_LIBRARY are not cleared
body:
### Environment details

* Operating System+version: Windows 10 & Linux
* Compiler+version: MSVC 19 & gcc 11.3.0
* Conan version: 2.0.2
* Python version: 3.10.6




### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a conan project with a dependecy and CMakeDeps generator
2. execute conan install
3. Have a look at the created cmakedeps_macros.cmake

in the function `conan_package_library_targets` line 23 the variable `CONAN_FOUND_LIBRARY` is filled with the found library. This call will write the variable into the cache. The same goes for the variable `CONAN_SHARED_FOUND_LIBRARY` in line 35. While this works for the first library in this foreach loop, each following call will not search for the library and update the variable, but takes them from the cache. So this way all the libraries end up with the same .lib and .dll files. So either the variable needs to be cleared after each foreach loop, or the NO_CACHE option needs to be used in the find_library execution. Another possible solution would be to create a new variable for every library (e.g. CONAN_FOUND_LIBRARY_${LIB_NAME} and CONAN_SHARED_FOUND_LIBRARY_${LIB_NAME})

### Logs

_No response_

title: [question] conan2 export-pkg fails for conanfile.py with python_requires dependency not in the local cache
body:
### What is your question?

Hi,

We started an experimental migration of our packages to conan 2.x.
Our packages use python_requires to declare a base dependency for our conanfiles which works fine with conan 1.x but has changed behaviour with conan 2.x

In our consumer conanfiles we use the following:
```
class MyPackageConan(ConanFile):
    name = "mypackage"
    version = "0.0.1"
    python_requires = "conan_file_base/2023.01"
    python_requires_extend = "conan_file_base.MyConanFileBase"
    ...
```
We then package the packages with conan export-pkg:

`conan export-pkg -r myremote mypackage/conanfile.py`

In case conan_file_base is not yet in the local cache, but available on the remote repository myremote export-pkg with conan 2.x seems to fail even though the remote is defined on the command line with -r myremote:
```
...
conan_file_base/2023.01: Not found in local cache, looking in remotes...                                                                                                                                                           
ERROR: Error loading conanfile at '.../mypackage/conanfile.py': Cannot resolve python_requires 'conan_file_base/2023.01': No remote defined
...
```

Explicitly downloading the python_requires dependency before export-pkg solves the issue:
`conan download conan_file_base/2023.01 -r myremote`

**Question**
- Is this an intended behavior change to enforce conan downloads for python_requires compared to conan 1.x?
The errror message "No remote defined" even though a remote is defined on the command line seems to suggest that this is a bug.

```
conan --version
Conan version 2.0.2
```

### Have you read the CONTRIBUTING guide?

- [X] I've read the CONTRIBUTING guide

title: [bug] Incorrect behavior when a common option is set twice for all dependencies & specific dependencies through configure()
body:
### Environment details

* Operating System+version: macOS Ventura
* Compiler+version: apple-clang 14
* Conan version: 2.0.0
* Python version: 3.11.2


### Steps to reproduce

Expected behavior: Force `shared=True` in all dependencies except few specific ones.

- The first approach through command line works fine:

  conanfile.py

  ```python
  from conan import ConanFile
  
  class FooConan(ConanFile):
      name = "foo"
      settings = "os", "arch", "compiler", "build_type"
  
      def requirements(self):
          self.requires("aaplus/2.41", force=True)
          self.requires("abseil/20230125.1", force=True)
          self.requires("bzip2/1.0.8", force=True)
          self.requires("zlib/1.2.13", force=True)
  ```
  
  ```
  conan install . -o "*:shared=True" -o "bzip/*:shared=False" -o "zlib/*:shared=False" -b missing
  ```

  `aaplus` & `abseil` are built as shared. `bzip2` & `zlib` as static. It's the expected behavior.

- The second approach where dependencies options are set in conanfile itself doesn't properly work:

  conanfile.py
  
  ```python
  from conan import ConanFile
  
  class FooConan(ConanFile):
      name = "foo"
      settings = "os", "arch", "compiler", "build_type"
  
      def configure(self):
          self.options["*"].shared = True
          self.options["bzip2"].shared = False
          self.options["zlib"].shared = False

      def requirements(self):
          self.requires("aaplus/2.41", force=True)
          self.requires("abseil/20230125.1", force=True)
          self.requires("bzip2/1.0.8", force=True)
          self.requires("zlib/1.2.13", force=True)
  ```
  
  ```
  conan install . -b missing
  ```

  `self.options["*"].shared = True` is ignored, `aaplus` & `abseil` are built with `shared=False` (default value of these 2 recipes). But If I remove `self.options["bzip2"].shared = False` & `self.options["zlib"].shared = False`, `shared=True` is honored in all dependencies...

The documentation about [build](https://docs.conan.io/2/reference/commands/build.html) command says:

```
usage: conan build [-h] [-v [V]] [--logger] [--name NAME] [--version VERSION] [--user USER] [--channel CHANNEL] [-of OUTPUT_FOLDER] [-b BUILD] [-r REMOTE | -nr] [-u] [-o OPTIONS_HOST] [-o:b OPTIONS_BUILD] [-o:h OPTIONS_HOST] [-pr PROFILE_HOST] [-pr:b PROFILE_BUILD]
                   [-pr:h PROFILE_HOST] [-s SETTINGS_HOST] [-s:b SETTINGS_BUILD] [-s:h SETTINGS_HOST] [-c CONF_HOST] [-c:b CONF_BUILD] [-c:h CONF_HOST] [-l LOCKFILE] [--lockfile-partial] [--lockfile-out LOCKFILE_OUT] [--lockfile-packages] [--lockfile-clean]
                   [path]

Install dependencies and call the build() method.

positional arguments:
  path                  Path to a folder containing a recipe (conanfile.py or conanfile.txt) or to a recipe file. e.g., ./my_project/conanfile.txt.
```

However, `conanfile.txt` is not acceptable by build command.

As the documentation is extracted from the command output, it should be fixed on Conan client first.


### Environment details

* Operating System+version: OSX 13
* Compiler+version: Apple-Clang 14
* Conan version: 2.0.0
* Python version: 3.10


### Steps to reproduce

1. mkdir /tmp/foo && cd /tmp/foo
2. echo "[requires]\nzlib/1.2.13" > conanfile.txt
3. conan build .
4. Or, conan build ./conanfile.txt

### Logs

```
% conan build .
ERROR: Conanfile not found at /private/tmp/foo/conanfile.py

% conan build ./conanfile.txt   
ERROR: A conanfile.py is needed, /private/tmp/conantxt/conanfile.txt is not acceptable
```

* Conan version:  2.0.0
* Python version: 3.8.10

### Steps to reproduce

Here is a complete Conan + CMake project that reproduces the issue.

**conanfile.py**
```python
from conan import ConanFile
from conan.tools.cmake import CMake, cmake_layout

class MyLib(ConanFile):
    name = "mylib"
    version = "0.1.0"
    description = "MyLib says hello"

    requires = [
        "openssl/[^1.1]"
    ]

    test_requires = [
        "gtest/cci.20210126",
    ]

    exports_sources = [

        "*.hpp",

    generators = "CMakeToolchain"

    settings = "os", "compiler", "build_type", "arch"

    def layout(self):

    def build(self):
        cmake = CMake(self)
        cmake.configure()
        cmake.build()

    def package(self):
        cmake = CMake(self)
        cmake.install()

    def package_info(self):
        self.cpp_info.components["mylib"].libs = ["mylib"]
        self.cpp_info.components["mylib"].requires = ["openssl::openssl"]
```

that will raise, a Conan protection that forces every pkg dependency to have components propagated.
Relax that assumption so this is allowed.

title: [question] Should Conan 2.0 export-pkg command process package_info?
body:
I'm seeing an issue when trying to run the export-pkg command on Windows. More specifically, during the export-pkg process, the conanfile.py method is called (as expected), which, in turn, calls Autotools.install. The issue arises due to the fact that this call needs the msys2 toolchain, which is specified in the recipe as a tool_requires in the build_requirements() method.

The msys2 package is available in the local cache, having been placed their when the standalone build command was run. However, it is not being found when the package() method is called in the export-pkg command because the conf settings ("tools.microsoft.bash:subsystem" and "tools.microsoft.bash:path"), which the msys2 recipe's package_info() method sets, have not been reestablished. Is this an oversight in the implementation of export-pkg or an incorrect use of package_info? If the latter, what is the recommended strategy and, if the former, let me know and I can turn this into a bug report.

As an aside, it seems to me that in Conan 2.0, where as I understand it, the package_folder is not available until the package() method is invoked, the package() method should be viewed as a build step and thus permitted to depend on tool_requires dependencies for its actions.

Thanks.

- [X] I've read the [CONTRIBUTING guide](https://github.com/conan-io/conan/blob/develop/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md).

title: [question] Managing multiple C++ packages within the same git repository
body:
- [x] I've read the [CONTRIBUTING guide](https://github.com/conan-io/conan/blob/develop/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md).
---
## Version
Conan Version: 1.54.0
## Summary
I have two projects using conanfile.py to manage their dependencies. Both are editable packages. Package B is dependent on Package A. Each time I try to install Package B, (`$ conan install ...`), it fails. I checked the command's logs and it looks like it is falling during or after (I can't tell) trying to retrieve Package A. I am confused about what I am doing wrong here.

title: [question] `transitive_headers` not working as expected
body:
I have the following situation: 
- I have a library `base` that depends on a library `audio` which depends on the `dr_wav` library.
- The `base` library includes the `audio.hpp` from the `audio` library which again includes the `dr_wav.h` header.

So there is a transitive header dependency to `dr_wav` from `base` and also from the `test_package` of the `audio` library.

```mermaid
graph TD;
    base-->audio;
    audio-->dr_wav;
    test_package_audio[audio test_package]-->audio;
    base-. transitive_headers .->dr_wav;
    test_package_audio-. transitive_headers .->dr_wav;
```

This works and builds fine when defining the `dr_wav` requires in `audio` with the `transitive_headers` option: `self.requires("drwav/0.13.7", transitive_headers=True)`

But now I also have a `test_package` for `base` which depends transitively on the `dr_wav.h` header:

```mermaid
graph TD;
    base-->audio;
    audio-->dr_wav;
    test_package_base[base test_package]-->base;
    test_package_base-. transitive_headers .->audio;
    test_package_base-. transitive_headers .->dr_wav;
```

I enabled the `transitive_headers` option also for the `audio` library dependency in `base`: `self.requires("audio/1.0.0", transitive_headers=True)`  
Now the `base test_package` can find the `audio.hpp` header file, but not the `dr_wav.h`. 
I also checked the `CMakeDeps` generated files in the `test_package` and the `drwav-release-x86_64-data.cmake` file does not include the header directory:

```cmake
set(drwav_INCLUDE_DIRS_RELEASE )
set(drwav_RES_DIRS_RELEASE )
set(drwav_DEFINITIONS_RELEASE )
set(drwav_SHARED_LINK_FLAGS_RELEASE )
set(drwav_EXE_LINK_FLAGS_RELEASE )
set(drwav_OBJECTS_RELEASE )
set(drwav_COMPILE_DEFINITIONS_RELEASE )
set(drwav_COMPILE_OPTIONS_C_RELEASE )
set(drwav_COMPILE_OPTIONS_CXX_RELEASE )
set(drwav_LIB_DIRS_RELEASE "${drwav_PACKAGE_FOLDER_RELEASE}/lib")
set(drwav_BIN_DIRS_RELEASE )
set(drwav_LIBRARY_TYPE_RELEASE STATIC)
set(drwav_IS_HOST_WINDOWS_RELEASE 0)
set(drwav_LIBS_RELEASE dr_wav)
set(drwav_SYSTEM_LIBS_RELEASE )
set(drwav_FRAMEWORK_DIRS_RELEASE )
set(drwav_FRAMEWORKS_RELEASE )
set(drwav_BUILD_DIRS_RELEASE )
set(drwav_NO_SONAME_MODE_RELEASE FALSE)
```

Am I missing something or could this even be a bug? I would expect transitive headers to be transitive over more than one dependency.

- [x] I've read the [CONTRIBUTING guide](https://github.com/conan-io/conan/blob/develop/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md).

EDIT:

Implementation of minimal example from above can be found here: https://github.com/Linux13524/conan-transitive-headers

title: [bug] prefix in pkg-config (.pc) file is emtpy when in editable mode
body:
I just updated conan to version 1.53.0 and am surprised that my .pc files generated with PkgConfigDeps into build/generators contain an empty prefix. This only when in editable mode. I use the layout() feature.

With conan 1.44
```
prefix=/home/dev/git/libname
libdir1=${prefix}/build/src
includedir1=${prefix}/include
includedir2=${prefix}/build/include
includedir3=${prefix}/build/include/libname
```

With conan 1.53
```
prefix=
libdir1=${prefix}/build/generators/build/src
includedir1=${prefix}/../../include
includedir2=${prefix}/../include
includedir3=${prefix}/../include/libname
```

Is this a bug or did I miss to migrate some variable in the layout() section.
Thanks

title: [bug] buildenv vs runenv for cmake.test() helper.
body:
Follow-up to #12407

I can see now why conan applies `[buildenv]` to this its `cmake.test` helper (since it's really `cmake --build <build_folder> --target test`), but it feels like many cases with shared libraries would also want the `[runenv]`. For example, they might need to find .dll files from libraries that were in requires. I would expect most test content to be pretty indifferent to the buildenv (unless doing something unusual, for example testing a header-only library by calling `$(CC) -fsyntax-only`).

But tests that call executable you just built (which linked to stuff in requires) don't seem that exotic. So I tested this, and it's indeed not working. I'm surprised I never hit that for real, but I guess I don't have *all* that many shared-library dependencies, and the one that is common (zlib1.dll) is kind of accidentally working because git for windows puts one in PATH, and I mostly live in git-bash.

### Environment Details (include every applicable attribute)
  * Operating System+version: Windows 10 200H2
  * Compiler+version: Visual Studio 2022 
  * Conan version: 1.53.0
  * Python version: 3.10.7

### Steps to reproduce (Include if Applicable)

`conan create conanfile.py -pr conanprofile.txt`

<details>
<summary>conanfile.py</summary>

```py
from conan import ConanFile
from conan.tools.cmake import CMake

class CTestConan(ConanFile):
    name = "ctest"
    version = "1.0"
    settings = "os", "compiler", "build_type", "arch"
    default_options = {"zlib:shared": True}
    generators = "CMakeToolchain", "CMakeDeps"
    requires = "zlib/1.2.12"

    exports_sources = "CMakeLists.txt", "main.cpp"

    def build(self):
        cmake = CMake(self)
        cmake.configure()
        cmake.build()
        cmake.test()
        # self.run("ctest", cwd=self.build_folder, run_environment=True)
        #self.run("ctest", cwd=self.build_folder, env=["conanbuild","conanrun"])

    def package_info(self):
        self.cpp_info.libs = ["hello"]
```
</details>

<details>
<summary>CMakeLists.txt</summary>

```cmake
cmake_minimum_required(VERSION 3.23)
project(test LANGUAGES CXX)

find_package(ZLIB)

add_executable(main main.cpp)
target_link_libraries(main ZLIB::ZLIB)

enable_testing()
add_test(NAME main COMMAND main)
add_test(NAME zlib1 COMMAND where zlib1.dll)
add_test(NAME env COMMAND ${CMAKE_COMMAND} -E environment)
```
</details>

<details>
<summary>main.cpp</summary>

```c++
#include <zlib.h>
int main() {
	z_stream zs = {};
	inflateInit(&zs);
	inflateEnd(&zs);
}
```
</details>

<details>
<summary>conanprofile.txt</summary>

```ini
[buildenv]
BUILDENV=1
[runenv]
RUNENV=1
[conf]
tools.env.virtualenv:auto_use=True
```
</details>

### Logs (Executed commands with output) (Include/Attach if Applicable)

If run from cmd (with no other zlib1.dll already in PATH from some random place), main fails with Exit code 0xc0000135 (STATUS_DLL_NOT_FOUND) and <build_folder>/Testing/Temporary/LastTest.log shows 

> 1/3 Test: main Exit code 0xc0000135

> 2/3 Test: zlib1
> Command: "C:/Windows/System32/where.exe" "zlib1.dll"
> Output:
> INFO: Could not find files for the given pattern(s).

> 3/3 Test: env
> Command: "C:/Program Files/CMake/bin/cmake.exe" "-E" "environment"
> BUILDENV=1

but no `RUNENV=1` -- so `[buildenv]` was applied, but not `[runenv]`. This is what I expected from #12407, but it seems like we would want `[runenv]` too when running tests.

---

If run from git-bash instead of cmd, all 3 tests "pass", but the _build_folder_/Testing/Temporary/LastTest.log shows that this is because we found zlib1 from mingw64:

> 3/3 Test: zlib1
> Command: "C:/Windows/System32/where.exe" "zlib1.dll"
> Output:
>C:\Program Files\Git\mingw64\bin\zlib1.dll

And that's why main.exe succeeded, that was enough to make a simple executable load and close enough to not crash. But we've mismatched versions/settings/options pretty much freely, since conan had no part in picking this one.

---

If I replace the `cmake.test()` with a `self.run("ctest", cwd=self.build_folder, run_environment=True)`, then PATH gets `%CONAN_USER_HOME%\.conan\data\zlib\1.2.12\_\_\package\ad5261bf6074807e7189c351b0f79b113bf2f6c0\bin`, and so main.exe gets the correct zlib1.dll. But it still doesn't get the `[runenv]RUNENV=1`, so apparently `run_environment=True` still does not pick up the profile's `[runenv]`?

If I try to get both by passing a list, i.e.`self.run("ctest", cwd=self.build_folder, env=["conanbuild","conanrun"])`, I unexpected get neither `[buildenv]` nor `[runenv]`.

The documentation at https://docs.conan.io/en/latest/reference/conanfile/other.html#output-and-running says this should work
> the environment or list of environment activations scripts to pre-pend to the given `command`. 

but the code to force a single `str` into into a list:

https://github.com/conan-io/conan/blob/5bf9aacedf9cc71c52ef548b079285715b51ba10/conans/model/conan_file.py#L441

will just end up in its `else []` case if the caller actually anything other than `str`

### Suggested fix

So it seems like Conanfile.run(env=...) should be fixed to recognize `isinstance(list)` (as is already documented), and then CMake.test -> CMake._build should pass in `env=["conanbuild","conanrun"]`, rather than just "conanbuild".

https://github.com/conan-io/conan/blob/5bf9aacedf9cc71c52ef548b079285715b51ba10/conan/tools/cmake/cmake.py#L157-L158
https://github.com/conan-io/conan/blob/5bf9aacedf9cc71c52ef548b079285715b51ba10/conan/tools/cmake/cmake.py#L127

title: [bug] Help for Conan 2 "source" command appears to be incorrect

labels.name: component: ux
labels.description: No changes to core business logic

body:
The help text for the Conan 2.0 "source" command summary reads:

> Install + calls the build() method

whereas I believe it should say 

> Calls the source() method

Additionally, it is confusing as to whether the "path" positional argument is optional or required. By observation, it appears to be required, but the help syntax shows it as optional (if one follows the convention that brackets denote optional arguments). Thus, it might be clearer if:

> usage: conan source [-h] [-v [V]] [--logger] [--name NAME] [--version VERSION]
>                     [--user USER] [--channel CHANNEL]
>                     [path]

were changed to

> usage: conan source [-h] [-v [V]] [--logger] [--name NAME] [--version VERSION]
>                     [--user USER] [--channel CHANNEL]
>                     path

or

> usage: conan source [-h] [-v [V]] [--logger] [--name NAME] [--version VERSION]
>                     [--user USER] [--channel CHANNEL]
>                     \<path\>

### Environment Details (include every applicable attribute)
  * Operating System+version: all
  * Compiler+version: all
  * Conan version: 2.0.0-beta4
  * Python version: all

### Steps to reproduce (Include if Applicable)

conan-2.0 --help

or

conan-2.0 source --help

### Logs (Executed commands with output) (Include/Attach if Applicable)

> $ conan-2.0 source --help
> usage: conan source [-h] [-v [V]] [--logger] [--name NAME] [--version VERSION]
>                     [--user USER] [--channel CHANNEL]
>                     [path]
> 
> Install + calls the build() method
> 
> positional arguments:
>   path               Path to a folder containing a recipe (conanfile.py or
>                      conanfile.txt) or to a recipe file. e.g.,
>                      ./my_project/conanfile.txt.
> 
> optional arguments:
>   -h, --help         show this help message and exit
>   -v [V]             Level of detail of the output. Valid options from less
>                      verbose to more verbose: -vquiet, -verror, -vwarning,
>                      -vnotice, -vstatus, -v or -vverbose, -vv or -vdebug, -vvv

title: [bug] Conan v2 think that macOS SDK is an iOS SDK
body:
<!--
  Please don't forget to update the issue title.
  Include all applicable information to help us reproduce your problem.

  To help us debug your issue please explain:
-->

### Environment Details (include every applicable attribute)
  * Operating System+version: macos latest
  * Compiler+version: clang 14
  * Conan version: 1.53
  * Python version: 3.9

### Steps to reproduce (Include if Applicable)

```
git clone https://github.com/nativium/nativium.git -b fix-conan-1-53
cd nativium
python3 nativium.py conan setup
python3 nativium.py target ios setup --arch=arm64 --build=debug --group=ios
python3 nativium.py target ios build --arch=arm64 --build=debug --group=ios
```

### Logs (Executed commands with output) (Include/Attach if Applicable)

```
CMake Error at /opt/homebrew/Cellar/cmake/3.24.2/share/cmake/Modules/Platform/iOS-Initialize.cmake:4 (message):
  
  /Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer/Platforms/MacOSX.platform/Developer/SDKs/MacOSX12.3.sdk
  is not an iOS SDK
Call Stack (most recent call first):
  /opt/homebrew/Cellar/cmake/3.24.2/share/cmake/Modules/CMakeSystemSpecificInitialize.cmake:21 (include)
  CMakeLists.txt:8 (project)
```

The problem is here:
https://github.com/nativium/nativium/blob/fix-conan-1-53/conan/darwin-toolchain/conanfile.py#L102

The `XCRun` object from conan don't check correctly the settings. It get the settings from conanfile, but need be something like i do, that is try to get `settings_target`. Or make XCRun receive `settings` and not `conanfile`:

```
settings_target = None

if hasattr(self, "settings_target"):
    settings_target = self.settings_target
    self.output.info("Settings: Target")
else:
    settings_target = self.settings
    self.output.info("Settings: Default")
```

The conan XCRun lines is here:
https://github.com/conan-io/conan/blob/develop/conan/tools/apple/apple.py#L82-L87

title: [bug] Bazel generator add tools and build dependencies as bazel deps
body:
### Environment Details (include every applicable attribute)
  * Operating System+version: Any
  * Compiler+version: Not relevant
  * Conan version: 1.51.2 and 1.52.0 , but maybe all since the bazel generator exists
  * Python version: 3.10.6 , but not relevant

### Steps to reproduce (Include if Applicable)

Install / use a package like `mongo-c-driver` and use the bazel generator to get a bazel file

```
    deps = [
        # do not sort
        ":mongoc-static-1.0_precompiled",
        ":bson-static-1.0_precompiled",
        "@openssl",
        "@snappy",
        "@zlib",
        "@zstd",
        "@icu",
        "@pkgconf",
    ],
```

`"@pkgconf"` is a tool and build requirement. 

Please have a look at the recipe:
https://github.com/conan-io/conan-center-index/blob/5225f30ee00d5f295419dc632cd29d4491a9d394/recipes/mongo-c-driver/all/conanfile.py#L94

Such build or tool requirements should not be on the list of dependencies.  They might not even exist in case of cross-compiling.

title: [bug] MAP_IMPORTED_CONFIG_* does not work in CMakeDeps
body:
Hello, sorry for unformatted issue!

In #11788 @lasote changed the way how dependencies handled by introducing new targets ([here](https://github.com/conan-io/conan/blame/develop/conan/tools/cmake/cmakedeps/templates/target_configuration.py#L70) and [here](https://github.com/conan-io/conan/blame/develop/conan/tools/cmake/cmakedeps/templates/target_configuration.py#L150)). It seems that these targets were forgotten to mark `IMPORTED`.

The specific problem: this change breaks our build, where we are using dependencies with `build_type=Release`, while building consumer with any other `build_type` (e.g. `RelWithDebInfo`). We are doing this by carefully maintain the `CMAKE_MAP_IMPORTED_CONFIG_*` in consumer.

title: [bug][conan v2] Command download with package query not working
body:
After trying several `conan download` commands, the package query flag does not work as expected:

```
$ conan download expat/2.2.10 -p os=Linux -r ccv2stg
ERROR: Specify a recipe revision or a wildcard. e.g: expat/2.2.10#*

$ conan download expat/2.2.10#* -p os=Linux -r ccv2stg
ERROR: 500: org.jfrog.repomd.conan.exceptions.ConanInfoException: Missing section in conaninfo.txt. [Remote: ccv2stg]

$ conan download expat/2.2.10#b9c4334d77b84fb5e9ee403d262e8072 -p os=Linux -r ccv2stg
ERROR: 500: org.jfrog.repomd.conan.exceptions.ConanInfoException: Missing section in conaninfo.txt. [Remote: ccv2stg]
```

Note `ccv2stg` remote is a repository in Artifactory with conan v2-beta2 generated packages uploaded.

Also, it will be very useful to have a way to download all pacakges, for example providing a query like `-p *`.

title: [bug] build_id broken in 2.0-beta
body:
<!--
  Please don't forget to update the issue title.
  Include all applicable information to help us reproduce your problem.

  To help us debug your issue please explain:
-->

### Environment Details (include every applicable attribute)
  * Operating System+version: Ubuntu 20.04 (docker)
  * Compiler+version: gcc9
  * Conan version: 2.0-beta2
  * Python version: 3.8.10

### Steps to reproduce (Include if Applicable)
I have a use case where I want to create multiple versions of a package that takes a while to build.  I use the build_id function so that I only have to build once.  The different versions have different options and different dependencies (some of the options effect the requirements).  Here is some code that worked just fine in conan 1.x
```
def build_id(self):
    # We don't want the option or the requirement to impact the build_id
    self.info_build.options.with_zeromq = "Any"
    if self.options.with_zeromq:
        self.info_build.requires.remove("zeromq")
```
In the 2.0-beta, the `remove` fails with a `KeyError`.  I was able to trace the error to conans/model/dependencies.py::__delitem__.
```
def __delitem__(self, name):
        r = self.get(name)
        del self._data[r]
```
`self.get` returns a `conans.model.info.RequirementInfo` object and the `self._data` keys are `conans.model.requires.Requirement` objects.  Thus the `del self._data[r]` command fails with a KeyError.


### Logs (Executed commands with output) (Include/Attach if Applicable)

<!--
  Your log content should be related to the bug description, it can be:
  - Conan command output
  - Server output (Artifactory, conan_server)
-->
ERROR: test_package/1.0.0: Error in build_id() method, line 378
        self.info_build.requires.remove("zeromq")
        KeyError: <conans.model.info.RequirementInfo object at 0x7f75b69d9ac0>

title: [question] Autotools.install() does not convert DESTDIR to unix path
body:
The new [Autotools](https://docs.conan.io/en/latest/reference/conanfile/tools/gnu/autotools.html) does not consider the path format when installing a package:

https://github.com/conan-io/conan/blob/develop/conan/tools/gnu/autotools.py#L58

It works well on Linux/Mac and any other unix system, but on Windows, it forces the regular path with backslash (\) which is skipped.

So far, I needed to do a workaround:

```python
autotools = Autotools(self)
destdir = unix_path(self, self.package_folder) if (self.settings.os == "Windows" and self.settings.compiler == "gcc") else self.package_folder
autotools.install([f"DESTDIR={destdir}"])
```

### Environment Details (include every applicable attribute)

  * Compiler+version: GCC 8 (msys official Conan package)

title: [bug] Package using apply_conandata_patches() sometimes throws exception when built in both Build and Host profile
body:
### Environment Details
  * Operating System+version: Debian Buster
  * Compiler+version: GCC 8.3  on Debian
  * Conan version: 1.51.2
  * Python version: 3.7

I've used zlib/1.2.12 as a reproducer because it was recently updated to use `conan.tools.files.apply_conandata_patches()` and started causing internal build failures.  This particular package ends up getting built twice by our consumer conanfile.py: once in the host context due to a direct dependency, plus a second time in the build context due to a protobuf tool_requires that pulls in the library again.

A minimal Debian conanfile.txt reproducer for this bug report is attached: [reproducer.tar.gz](https://github.com/conan-io/conan/files/9312899/reproducer.tar.gz)

I also reproduced this on macOS with Python 3.9 and the apple-clang compiler provided by Xcode 13.4.1.

### Steps to Reproduce

Create a conanfile.txt with the zlib/1.2.12 declared in both the build_requires and tool_requires section, then define separate build and host profiles as per the [cross building docs][cross-build]. The separate architectures require two different package builds:

```
conanfile.txt: Installing package
Requirements
    zlib/1.2.12 from 'conancenter' - Cache
Packages
    zlib/1.2.12:9f5d845a9acd4104ba44865c80f5b042812f136e - Build
Build requirements
    zlib/1.2.12 from 'conancenter' - Cache
Build requirements packages
    zlib/1.2.12:1cfd15a0464c4b1c680c61895450fbdbe189331c - Build
```

[cross-build]: https://docs.conan.io/en/latest/systems_cross_building/cross_building.html

Invoke `conan install` with `--build "zlib"` to force the zlib package to build twice: once in the host profile, which will always pass, and then a second time in the build profile. This second build dies on an exception thrown by `conan.tools.apply_conandata_packages`:

```
ERROR: zlib/1.2.12: Error in build() method, line 86
	self._patch_sources()
while calling '_patch_sources', line 70
	apply_conandata_patches(self)
	ConanException: The 'conandata.yml' file needs a 'patch_file' or 'patch_string' entry for every patch to be applied
```

Inserting a try-catch and breakpoint into the exported zlib recipe shows that `self.conan_data` has corrupted patch data (this might just a missing deep copy when instantiating the second ZlibConanfile instance from the catch?):

```
> /home/developer/Scratch/bug-report/.conan/data/zlib/1.2.12/_/_/export/conanfile.py(74)_patch_sources()
-> pass
(Pdb) list
 69  	    def _patch_sources(self):
 70  	        try:
 71  	            apply_conandata_patches(self)
 72  	        except Exception as e:
 73  	            import pdb; pdb.set_trace()
 74  ->	            pass
 75  	
 76  	        is_apple_clang12 = self.settings.compiler == "apple-clang" and Version(self.settings.compiler.version) >= "12.0"
 77  	        if not is_apple_clang12:
 78  	            for filename in ['zconf.h', 'zconf.h.cmakein', 'zconf.h.in']:
 79  	                filepath = os.path.join(self.source_folder, filename)
(Pdb) e
ConanException("The 'conandata.yml' file needs a 'patch_file' or 'patch_string' entry for every patch to be applied")
(Pdb) self.conan_data
{'patches': {'1.2.12': [{}, {}]}, 'sources': {'1.2.12': {'sha256': '91844808532e5ce316b3c010929493c0244f3d37593afd6de04f71821d5136d9', 'url': 'https://zlib.net/fossils/zlib-1.2.12.tar.gz'}}}
```

For reference, zlib/1.2.12 should have two patch files defined:

```
❯ cat .conan/data/zlib/1.2.12/_/_/export/conandata.yml 
patches:
  1.2.12:
  - patch_file: patches/0001-fix-cmake.patch
  - patch_file: patches/0002-gzguts-xcode12-compile-fix.patch
sources:
  1.2.12:
    sha256: 91844808532e5ce316b3c010929493c0244f3d37593afd6de04f71821d5136d9
    url: https://zlib.net/fossils/zlib-1.2.12.tar.gz
```

title: [bug] Targets defined by CMakeDeps generator have incorrect target libraries
body:
After updating to conan 1.51.2, I started getting link errors when trying to build my project in Visual Studio. This affected all configurations except for Debug. 

After some investigation I noticed that all configurations of some of the dependencies were present in additional dependencies list. (e.g. both `spdlog.lib` and `spdlogd.lib` were present in the project dependencies for Release configuration)

Looking further into it I found that this happens when dependencies have different lib names based on the configuration (e.g. `spdlog.lib` for Release and `spdlogd.lib` for Debug)

The bug is caused by not using generator expressions for `<pkg_name>_LIBRARIES_TARGETS` when defining `INTERFACE_LINK_LIBRARIES` target property in generated CMake files.

This has also been fixed by [this](https://github.com/conan-io/conan/commit/307bb66ba5bb816cdd5768288ea4e277ba7a6388) commit, and then immediately broken by [this](https://github.com/conan-io/conan/commit/91933762620e55e54bb9a9576983a162ae645f13) refactoring commit

### Environment Details (include every applicable attribute)
  * Operating System+version: Windows 10
  * Compiler+version: MSVC 19.33.31629.0
  * Conan version: 1.51.2
  * Python version: 3.8.5

title: [bug] Modify checksums defaults to `None`
body:
`get` function (and `download`) uses this signature `def get(conanfile, url, md5='', sha1='', sha256='',...)`. IMHO it would be better to use defaults `None` and check always explicitly using `if sha256 is not None` instead of `if sha256`.

Changing the approach would prevent some _malicious_ code like in the following `conandata.yml`:

```yaml
sources:
  "0.0.18":
    url: "https://blend2d.com/download/blend2d-beta18.zip"
    sha256: ""
  "0.0.17":
    url: "https://blend2d.com/download/blend2d-beta17.zip"
    sha256: "06ee8fb0bea281d09291e498900093139426501a1a7f09dba0ec801dd340635e"
```

Here, the CCI validation (hooks) is successful because `sha256` entry exists and it is a string. Of course, something to improve there, but I think the client would also benefit from this change.

title: [feature] Conan tools.scm.Version became very difficult to use
body:
With the introduction of the new [tools.scm.Version](https://docs.conan.io/en/latest/reference/conanfile/tools/scm/other.html#version), it no longer parses `semver` as described on the documentation, but also makes users life harder. Comparing both `Version` behavior, we have:


```python
from conans import tools as tools_legacy
from conan.tools import scm

VERSION = "1.2.3"

if __name__ == "__main__":
    legacy_version = tools_legacy.Version(VERSION)
    print(f"Legacy Version: {legacy_version}")
    print(f"Major: {legacy_version.major} - Minor: {legacy_version.minor} - Patch: {legacy_version.patch}")

    version = scm.Version(VERSION)
    print(f"New version: {version}")
    print(f"Major: {version.major(fill=False)} - Minor: {version.minor(fill=False)} - Patch: {version.patch()}")
    print(f"Major: {version[0]} - Minor: {version[1]} - Patch: {version[2]}")
```

Output:

```
Legacy Version: 1.2.3
Major: 1 - Minor: 2 - Patch: 3
New version: 1.2.3
Major: 1 - Minor: 1.2 - Patch: 1.2.3
Major: 1 - Minor: . - Patch: 2
```

So far, we needed to dig an index to parse and use what we want: https://github.com/conan-io/conan-center-index/pull/12083#pullrequestreview-1064201491

My suggestion is adding a pattern support to `Version` where we could extend it:

    version = Version('1.2.3', pattern='semver')
    version.major # Yes, it's a property, not a method.

Or, we could provide new classes, with Version as the base:

```python
from conan.tools.scm import SemVersion

version = SemVersion('1.2.3')
version.major # Yes, it's a property, not an method.
```


- [ X ] I've read the [CONTRIBUTING guide](https://github.com/conan-io/conan/blob/develop/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md).

title: [feature] Implement `get_safe` in develop for self.info objects
body:
In Conan 2.X there is `get_safe` over `self.info.settings` and `self.info.options` but there is not in Conan 1.X.
It is needed when, for example, there is a `header_only` option and you need to check in the validate some stuff.

Related https://github.com/conan-io/conan/issues/11786

title: [bug] self.export_sources_folder is empty in local build
body:
### Environment Details
  * Operating System+version: Linux Mint 20.3
  * Compiler+version: gcc 9
  * Conan version: 1.51
  * Python version: 3.8.10

### Steps to reproduce
```
conan install . -pr:h host -if build
conan source . -sf build
conan build . -bf build -sf build
```

In both `source()` and `build()` methods `self.export_sources_folder` is empty. If I use `conan create`, it's the same as `self.source_folder`.

This breaks the `patch` tool which uses `export_sources_folder` internally.

title: [bug] system lib (dl) ordering change on link
body:
### Environment Details (include every applicable attribute)
  * Operating System+version: Debian bullseye
  * Compiler+version: gcc 11
  * Conan version: 1.51
  * Python version: 3.9.2

### Steps to reproduce (Include if Applicable)
Not easy, but lot of dependencies and openssl with dl usage (using crypto)

### Logs (Executed commands with output) (Include/Attach if Applicable)
```
/usr/bin/c++  -pipe -Wall -fstack-protector-all -fstack-check -O3 -DNDEBUG  -Wl,-z,relro -Wl,--as-needed CMakeFiles/bin_beauty_application_singleton.dir/beauty_application_singleton.cpp.o -o ../../../bin/beauty_application_singleton  ../../../lib/libbeauty.a /home/dfleury/.conan/data/openssl/1.1.1q/_/_/package/fae585d7c68637b721c0c4c0d1c52174d067eda8/lib/libssl.a -ldl /home/dfleury/.conan/data/openssl/1.1.1q/_/_/package/fae585d7c68637b721c0c4c0d1c52174d067eda8/lib/libcrypto.a -lrt -lpthread -lstdc++fs 
```

Here -ldl is placed before crypto.a, so I get 
```
usr/bin/ld: /home/dfleury/.conan/data/openssl/1.1.1q/_/_/package/fae585d7c68637b721c0c4c0d1c52174d067eda8/lib/libcrypto.a(dso_dlfcn.o): in function `dlfcn_globallookup':
dso_dlfcn.c:(.text+0x13): undefined reference to `dlopen'
```

If I use conan 1.49 or conan 1.50, it works fine.
```
usr/bin/c++  -pipe -Wall -fstack-protector-all -fstack-check -O3 -DNDEBUG  -Wl,-z,relro -Wl,--as-needed CMakeFiles/bin_beauty_chat.dir/beauty_chat.cpp.o -o ../../../bin/beauty_chat  ../../../lib/libbeauty.a /home/dfleury/.conan/data/openssl/1.1.1q/_/_/package/fae585d7c68637b721c0c4c0d1c52174d067eda8/lib/libssl.a /home/dfleury/.conan/data/openssl/1.1.1q/_/_/package/fae585d7c68637b721c0c4c0d1c52174d067eda8/lib/libcrypto.a /home/dfleury/.conan/data/openssl/1.1.1q/_/_/package/fae585d7c68637b721c0c4c0d1c52174d067eda8/lib/libcrypto.a -ldl -lpthread -lrt -lstdc++fs 
```

title: [bug] Variable XXX_LIBRARIES not populated in Conan >=1.51

Looks like the variable that previously contained the library names stopped being populated.

title: [package] boost/*: CMakeDeps generator broken for Conan 1.51.0
body:
### Package and Environment Details

* Package Name/Version: **conan/1.79.0**
* Operating System+version: **Fedora Linux 36**
* Compiler+version: **GCC 12**
* Conan version: **conan 1.51.0**
* Python version: **Python 3.10.5**


### Conan profile

conan profile show linux/gcc/debug
Configuration for profile linux/gcc/debug:

[settings]
os=Linux
arch=x86_64
compiler=gcc
compiler.version=12
compiler.libcxx=libstdc++11
compiler.cppstd=17
build_type=Debug
[options]
[conf]
[build_requires]
[env]

### Steps to reproduce

1. Use CMakeDeps generator with the Boost package from Conan Center as a `requires`.
2. Run `conan install`.
3. Run `conan build`, where the configure stage of CMake will fail.
